FamilyMart Uny Holdings (8028 JT) - Co. is reportedly to permit franchisees to shorten their store hours. (Nikkei)

Recruit Holdings (6098 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 114.2bln vs. Prev. JPY 92.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Shinsei Bank (8303 JT) - Co. H1 net JPY 28.2bln vs. Prev. JPY 27.7bln Y/Y, while Suruga Bank (8358 JT) confirmed entry into alliance agreement with the Co. (Newswires)

JPY 1.78tln Y/Y, Co. lowers FY net guidance to loss of JPY 152bln and will launch tender offer for 3 listed units for around JPY 200bln as speculated. (Newswires)

NCSoft (036570 KS) - Co. Q3 net KRW 113.3bln vs. Prev. KRW 94.4bln Y/Y, oper. profit KRW 128.9bln vs. Exp. KRW 113bln, rev. KRW 397.8bln vs. Exp. KRW 398bln. (Newswires)

content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said that the trade deal with China is moving along very rapidly. (Newswires)

US-China trade talks have hit a snag over agricultural purchases according to reports which added that China is leery of putting a numerical figure on its commitment in the next potential agreement to avoid making the deal seem one-sided in Washington's favour. Furthermore, Chinese officials were said to have been resisting US demands for strong enforcement mechanisms and curbs on forced tech transfers. (WSJ)

China Cabinet said it will lower capital ratio requirement for some infrastructural investment projects. (Newswires)

Global Times tweeted that US warship movements are under the surveillance of the Chinese military, who will defend their national sovereignty and territorial integrity citing a PLA Eastern Command Spokesman. (Twitter)

Chinese Universities in Hong Kong will cancel all of their on-campus classes for November in Hong Kong. (SCMP)

Indian CPI Inflation (Oct) Y/Y 4.62% vs. Exp. 4.25% (Prev. 3.99%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Brexit Party Leader Farage said the party will not stand down any further candidates and reports indicated that the Brexit Party are irritated that no reciprocity has been displayed from the Conservative Party on this. (Sky)

ComRes UK election poll showed Conservatives at 40% (+3), Labour at 30% (+1), Lib Dems 16% (-1), Brexit 7% (-2) in survey conducted November 11th-12th. (Twitter)

  • UK CPI (Oct) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.7%). (Newswires)
  • EU Industrial Production (Sep) M/M 0.1% vs. Exp. -0.3% (Prev. 0.4%)
  • EU Industrial Production (Sep) Y/Y -1.7% vs. Exp. -2.3% (Prev. -2.8%)

 

FX

SNB's President Jordan said monetary policy with negative interest rates and a readiness to intervene is still necessary, while he added that CHF remains highly valued. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Stocks -0.54mln vs. Exp. +1.60mln (Prev. +4.26mln). (Newswires)

US EIA cut 2019 world oil demand growth by 90k BPD to a 750k BPD Y/Y rise but raised 2020 world oil demand growth by 70k BPD to a 1.37mln BPD Y/Y increase. Furthermore, it stated US crude output expected to rise 1.3mln BPD to 12.29mln BPD in 2019 (Prev. forecast expected a 1.27mln BPD increase), while US crude output expected to rise 1mln BPD to 13.29mln BPD in 2020 (Prev. forecast expected a rise to 13.17mln BPD). (Newswires)

OPEC SecGen Barkindo said it is too early to say if further output cuts are needed and that fundamentals of global economy remain strong and that crude demand numbers for 2020 has potential for an upside swing, while he added there may be a sharp reduction of supply estimates going into 2020 especially from US shale. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister has not seen huge fluctuations in oil supply and demand due to good work of OPEC and OPEC+. (Newswires) 

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said the Syrian ceasefire is holding very well and the Kurds seem satisfied, while added the US left troops in Syria only to secure the oil and that he will be talking with Turkish President Erdogan about a potential trade deal. (Newswires)

US Defense Secretary Esper said US is open to alterations in military activity on the Korean Peninsula to support North Korea diplomacy. (Newswires) 

 

US

US President Trump noted that he has been fully briefed on auto tariffs and will be making a decision fairly soon. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell said the current stance of monetary policy is 'likely to remain appropriate' as long as incoming data is largely consistent with the economic outlook and the baseline outlook for the economy remains favourable but noteworthy risks to the outlook remain. Powell also stated that persistent below-target inflation may lead to a slide in the longer-term inflation expectations and repeated if developments result in a material reassessment of the Fed's outlook then the Bank will respond accordingly. Furthermore, Powell suggested the labour market is not sending any signal that it is too hot and that there is a lot to like about the labour market today, while he does not see wages moving upwards in an inflationary manner and noted negative interest rates would certainly not be appropriate in the current environment. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (non-voter) said rate cuts this year have put monetary policy in a very good place while Daly added she is open to the idea that risks are on the downside but noted that the Fed's stance is right so far. (Newswires)

  • US CPI NSA (Oct) Y/Y 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%). (Newswires)
  • US Real Weekly Earnings (Oct) M/M -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. -0.1%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Disney (DIS) caught a bid on strong Disney+ launch figures, Netflix (NFLX) chilled to the downside. Caterpillar (CAT) opened lower after disappointing 3-month rolling sales figures. Chesapeake Energy (CHK) surged on reports of a potential deal with Comstock. Tech Data (TECD) was firmer after Apollo agreed to buy it out for USD 5.4bln. Mosaic (MOS) fell victim to a downgrade at JPMorgan to Underweight. Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA) traded volatile after reports they were the focus of an FTC probe. S&P 500 0.1% at 3094, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 8260, Dow Jones 0.3% at 27783.

Yields were lower across the curve, with a bias towards narrower curve spreads, with the complex largely trading off of the over-arching risk tone from the APAC session and early European session, traversing sideways through US trade; US CPI, and a testimony from Fed chair Powell were digested with ease. There was some modest upside after the WSJ article on US/China trade talks hitting a snag, though the moves weren’t anything to write home about. US T-note (Z9) futures settled 11+ ticks higher at 128.28+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th November 2019: US/China trade talks reportedly hit a snag
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 13th November 2019: US/China trade talks reportedly hit a snag

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities flat, Treasuries higher, USD flat, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: US-China trade talks hit a snag; Powell sticks to script; firmer headline CPI

* COMING UP: Data: Australian Labour Force Report; Chinese Industrial Output, Retail Sales; German Flash GDP; UK Retail Sales; EU Flash Employment & GDP; US Initial Jobless Claims, Weekly EIA Inventories; OPEC Monthly Report. Events: Banxico Rate Decision. Speakers: Fed’s Harker, Quarles, Clarida, Evans, Powell, Daly, Williams, Bullard, Kaplan. ECB’s de Guindos, Lane, de Galhau. Supply: UK 30yr. Earnings: Merck (GY), National Grid, Burberry Group, Walmart, NVIDIA, Viacom.

 

* MARKETS WRAP: The market shed gains after WSJ reported China trade talks had hit a “snag”, with China hesitant to agree to a figure for ag. purchases or enforcement mechanisms, reversing fresh ATHs made earlier in the US session. However, albeit a negative shock, the move in ES was within ranges, with limited moves seen across other major asset classes; however, as traders digested the details, equities pared losses, for the SPX to trade flat. The risk-off tone was evident in European morning trade, with the financial sector weighed on by downbeat earnings from the Dutch bank, ABN AMRO. US CPI data in the pre-market, saw the headline beat expectations, but the data failed to garner much attention, where participants looked towards comments by Fed Chair Powell (released at the cash open), with the Fed chair largely sticking to the script. Accordingly, the North American open followed the tone of APAC and Europe, with cash equities falling at the open. Although a turnaround was seen shortly after, with stronger energy prices seeing the sector lead the pact. Participants are now looking towards Cisco (CSCO) earnings aftermarket - a tech bellwether - after the bell to get a glimpse into global demand, followed by Walmart (WMT) on Thursday, which will speak to the strength, or lack of, from the US consumer.

* TRADE: China trade talks had hit a “snag” and Beijing was reluctant to commit to a nominal figure of agricultural purchases, WSJ reported. The article also suggested that China did not want the deal to seem one sided, in addition to it resisting US demands for enforcement mechanisms and curbs on forced tech transfers. In regard to auto tariffs, Trump said that he had been fully briefed on them and that he would be making a decision fairly soon; reports earlier in the week suggested Trump was likely to delay the tariffs by six months again to focus on China. Looking back to Trump’s NY Econ Club speech on Tuesday, which lacked substance on key issues, SocGen's analysts argued (before the WSJ piece release) that Trump's remarks suggest that there are still some loose ends that need tying up, hence risk assets, bond yields and USDJPY have stalled. It also noted that the China side had gone quiet, in contrast to last week, when the roll-back of tariffs was being reported as a done deal.

* FED CHAIR POWELL: In his testimony to the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, Fed Chair Powell largely stuck to the script, as the Street was generally expecting. He repeated that the Fed's policy stance was "likely to remain appropriate" as long as incoming data was consistent with the Fed's outlook, repeating that if developments cause a material re-assessment in the Fed's outlook, it will respond accordingly. Powell was again upbeat on the US economy stating that the baseline remains favourable, and the Fed foresees a sustained expansion of activity, along with strong labour markets and inflation near its symmetric 2.0% goal as the most likely outcome. However, Powell did note that noteworthy risks to the US outlook still remain, with sluggish global growth and trade developments posing risks. Powell also warned that persistent below-target inflation might weigh on longer-term inflation expectations. Looking at asset prices, Powell noted that the level of vulnerabilities in the financial system were moderate, and investor appetite for risk was elevated in some asset classes, though the core of the financial sector appeared resilient. Powell also warned that the high level of US government debt might restrain the ability of fiscal policymakers to support the US economy in the event of a downturn.

* US CPI: There was a small upside surprise, with headline CPI rising 0.4% M/M against an expected rise of 0.3%, on the back of energy prices; the Y/Y rate ticked up by one-tenth to 1.8%. The Core M/M printed 0.2%, in line with the expected, while the core Y/Y rate rose by one-tenth to 2.4% (which some analysts said was consistent with the Fed's preferred PCE gauge running at a clip slightly below 2.0%). Analysts said that the larger rise in headline prices was on the back of higher gasoline prices, with little signs of September tariff hikes lifting consumer prices, just yet (ahead of the release of the October data, analysts had suggested the impact may be more visible in the November data). "We had expected to see some inflationary impact from the latest tranche of tariffs on Chinese imports imposed in early September, but prices of clothing and household furnishings declined in October," Capital Economics said, "meanwhile, there are some signs that underlying price pressures are beginning to moderate again, with shelter prices rising by a muted 0.1% m/m." Overall, however, Capital Economics argues that the October CPI data suggests core inflation is levelling off close to the Fed's 2% target, and that barring any sharp slowdown in economic activity, that supports the Fed’s stance of leaving interest rates on hold for an extended period.

* GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump said he and Turkish President Erdogan had talked about F-35 jets and expect a solution will be found, following the two meeting in Washington on Wednesday. In Hong Kong Chinse Universities will reportedly cancel all of their on-campus classes as violence continues; schools are also shut. In China, Global Times noted US warship movement is under the surveillance of Chinese military, with a PLA Eastern Command Spokesman adding it will defend its national sovereignty and territorial integrity. US Defense Secretary Esper said the US is open to alterations in military activity on the Korean Peninsula to support North Korea diplomacy.

* RBNZ: After releases signalled weaker NZ inflation expectations at the beginning of the week, pricing had more meaningfully tilted towards the rate cut camp; however, the RBNZ stood pat, holding rates at 1.00% and the  central bank arguing that developments since the August MPS did not warrant a change: (1) it said that NZ exports have held up well, while the terms of trade firm; 2) A lower NZD is serving to offset weaker global growth; 3) The impact of already undertaken easing was flowing into the economy; 4) Wages and non-tradeable inflation has been rising; 5) The economy is near full-employment; 6) longer-term inflation expectations are anchored. And since the August MPS report, data has come in in-line with, or better than the RBNZ had projected. TD Securities -- who was in the minority, and foresaw an unchanged decision -- said that the statement was not as dovish as it had anticipated; "There does not appear any urgency by the RBNZ to act at this point, with Gov Orr indicating monetary conditions are very stimulative at the moment," and "the key RBNZ forecasts are consistent with this view." However, TD notes that despite the positives stated above, the RBNZ suggests we are not out of the woods yet, with the post-meeting statement acknowledging that "the risks to the economy in the near term were tilted to the downside and agreed it would add further monetary stimulus if economic developments warranted it". Looking ahead, TD Securities is expecting a further lowering of rates, but says February's meeting may be too soon. "The RBNZ appears quite comfortable with current monetary policy settings, and our forecast for the RBNZ to cut in February is looking less likely." TD states that there are other factors that could enter the RBNZ equation: "Does the market return to pricing in the Fed cutting rates, the RBA moving towards QE and trade war tensions returning?" But in the near-term, the market is less likely to consider these as options. "With the RBNZ appearing in no rush to cut, and the possibility the RBNZ announces an easing in high LVR restrictions later this month, it makes a February cut harder to justify."

* EIA STEO: EIA released its short-term energy update; it cut 2019 world oil demand growth by 90k BPD to a 750k BPD Y/Y rise and raised 2020 world oil demand growth by 70k BPD to a 1.37mln BPD Y/Y increase. US crude output is expected to rise 1.3mln BPD to 12.29mln BPD in 2019 (prev. forecast expected a 1.27mln BPD increase), while output is expected to rise 1mln BPD to 13.29mln BPD in 2020 (prev. forecast expected a rise to 13.17mln BPD). Finally, the EIA said crude production is to exceed an average of 13mln BDP in Q4 2019, earlier than previous forecasts.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.32 HIGHER AT USD 57.12/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLED USD 0.31 HIGHER AT USD 62.37/BBL. Crude markets are higher, having pared early losses as macro sentiment turned around during US trading hours. Trade concerns had seen the complex fall as low as USD 56.20/bbl and USD 61.22/bbl in WTI and Brent front month contracts, before composure was regained the complex moved as high as USD 57.21/bbl and USD 62.55/bbl on the day. Potentially also providing some support to the price action; OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said the fundamentals of global economy remain strong and that crude demand numbers for 2020 have the potential for an upside swing. Moreover, he said that there could be a sharp reduction of supply estimates going into 2020, especially from US shale. Looking ahead, API Inventory data is set to be released after the US equity market close; crude stocks are seen building by 1.6mln bbls (as has been the case for over a month), gasoline is seen drawing 1.1mln bbls and distillates drawing 0.8mln bbls. Meanwhile, Genscape forecasts Cushing stocks drawing 1.2mln bbls.

* US T-NOTE (Z9) FUTURES SETTLED 11+ TICKS HIGHER AT 128-28+: Yields were lower across the curve, with a bias towards narrower curve spreads, with the complex largely trading off of the over-arching risk tone from the APAC session and early European session, traversing sideways through US trade; US CPI, and a testimony from Fed chair Powell were digested with ease. There was some modest upside after the WSJ article on US/China trade talks hitting a snag, though the moves weren’t anything to write home about.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.1% at 3094, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 8260, Dow Jones 0.3% at 27783.

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.4%, Consumer Staples 0.9%, Energy -0.5%, Financials -0.6%, Health Care 0.1%, Industrials -0.4%, Information Technology 0.3%, Materials -0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities 1.5%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Disney (DIS) caught a bid on strong Disney+ launch figures, Netflix (NFLX) chilled to the downside. Caterpillar (CAT) opened lower after disappointing 3-month rolling sales figures. Chesapeake Energy (CHK) surged on reports of a potential deal with Comstock. Tech Data (TECD) was firmer after Apollo agreed to buy it out for USD 5.4bln. Mosaic (MOS) fell victim to a downgrade at JPMorgan to Underweight. Visa (V) and Mastercard (MA) traded volatile after reports they were the focus of an FTC probe.

* EARNINGS: Datadog (DDOG) made double digit gains after beating EPS and Revenue estimates, whilst exceeding street expectations for guidance. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) opened lower, despite beating top and bottom line, after weak guidance. SmileDirectClub (SDC) dived lower amid guidance for more losses. Canada Goose (GOOS) was hit after disappointing guidance, despite a strong quarter.

* FX WRAP: USD traded marginally flat/firmer on Wednesday, yet again trading in tight ranges. DXY saw highs within a whisker of 98.50, and lows of 98.289, just above the 50dma at 98.285. EUR relatively subdued today; we remain on the look out for a definitive decision on US tariffs of European autos, which Trump said could be made soon. Haven’s were bid in early trade. with USDJPY trickling further beneath the 109 handle on a soft risk tone, aided by rate differentials; the 200dma as prices continue to be lead by anti-climatic update.  XAU slightly firmer today trading in an approximately 10 buck range, while CHF was bid; SNB’s Jordan reiterated policy with negative rates and a readiness to intervene is still necessary, highlighting the CHF being overvalued. EURCHF currently trades around ~1.09 level, with some noting that the 1.10 mark is regarded as an indicative level below which the SNB may consider an upgrade to its language on the CHF. NZD an outperformer today, as it rose by the most in a single day since January, sending NZDUSD above 0.64 after the RBNZ stood pat on policy despite expectations for a cut, stating that developments did not warrant a change to the already stimulatory monetary setting at this time. In EMFX, TRY regained some strength amid a friendly tone between President Trump and Erdogan in Washington. ZAR also slightly firmer against the buck despite continued Eskom worries and bleak SA retail sales. MXN weaker against the greenback briefly breaching 19.50 to the upside ahead of Thursday’s Banxico rate decision that could culminate in a bigger than forecast ½ point reduction. RUB also weaker despite some traction from firmer than consensus Russian Q3 growth, and a mild bounce in Brent.

* AUSTRALIA WAGES: The Aussie wage price index eased to 0.5% Q/Q and 2.2% Y/Y, in line with market expectations. The weakness in the data resulted in Australian bank Westpac stating that it would reassess its forecast for wage inflation to get back to 2.4% Y/Y in 2020; "Clearly, if policymakers would like to use market mechanisms to lift wages, they have a lot more work to do to get the unemployment rate down to a level that will generate a broad based sustainable wages pulse." The data comes ahead of Thursday's labour market data, which is expected to show 15k jobs being added to the Australian economy in October (prev. 14.7k), and the jobless rate likely to tick-up by one-tenth to 5.3% (participation expected unchanged at 66.1%).

* BANXICO PRIMER: Ten of the 14 analysts surveyed by Reuters look for Banxico to cut rates by 25bps to 7.50%, which would be the third successive rate cut, given low growth (0.1% in Q3), stable inflation (3.02% in October, the middle of Banxico’s 2-4% range), rising unemployment (up to 3.8% this October from 3.2% last year) and a relatively stable MXN continuing to give the bank room for further easing. A cut would also keep pace with the US Federal Reserve, which has also cut rates three times since the summer, with the US central bank now suggesting that its insurance cuts have concluded, and it has re-adopted its data-dependent stance, could also dissuade the board from taking more aggressive action. Four analysts polled by Reuters look for a deeper 50bps rate cut, following soft GDP data in Q3 (NOTE: two of the bank’s five board members voted for a 50bps cut at the last meeting). However, most desks argue that the board will err against providing the market with any kind of dovish surprise. TD Securities argues that "increasing the easing trajectory would likely result in the market pricing in too aggressive an easing profile into Mexican assets (steps of 50bps instead of 25bps)... could degrade the relatively EM-leading, and peso-supportive yield that has been crucial in minimizing the external risks to inflation (via violent MXN depreciation) that have allowed Banxico to begin its easing process in the first place." Other factors contributing to a more cautious approach by Banxico include; the risk of credit rating downgrades, the risk of another sharp increase in the minimum wage in 2020 and the risk of policy-triggered market instability following policy announcements by the Mexican administration, or the US ahead of the Presidential election campaign season. Looking ahead, markets expect Banxico finally “de-couple” from the Fed with a 25bps cut in December, after which the bank is then expected to pursue further easing. Money markets have priced in 75bps worth of easing through the year-end (including the potential 25bps cut this week). With real rates well within restrictive territory at near 4% combined with the benign inflation outlook, analysts at ING see the Banxico delivering a steady pace of 25bp cuts, until the policy rate drops to 6.5% at least.

Looking ahead, API Inventory data is set to be released after the US equity market close; crude stocks are seen building by 1.6mln bbls (as has been the case for over a month), gasoline is seen drawing 1.1mln bbls and distillates drawing 0.8mln bbls. Meanwhile, Genscape forecasts Cushing stocks drawing 1.2mln bbls.

subject: Fed Chair Powell says labour market is not sending any signal that it is too hot, adding there is a lot to like about the labour market today, does not see wages moving upwards in an inflationary manner
content:
On Policy

  • Negative interest rates would certainly not be appropriate in the current environment

On the economy

  • Questions why there has not been more of an uptick in wages, says it is puzzling
  • The new normal is lower interest rates, inflation and economic growth
  • Reiterates fed's line that uncertainty around future trade policy is weighing on business sentiment and investment
  • US economy is in a really good place

On repo-operations

  • Fed is still very much looking at what happened in the repo market, thinks it has the issues under control

On Fiscal policy

  • Low interest rates do not mean the US government can ignore deficits, adding there is a need to reduce the US deficit
  • Reiterates does not consider political factors in deciding the course of interest rates
  • Notes fiscal policy is often a big part of the answer during a severe downturn, in the event of a downturn he would call on that to be the case again

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar unfazed by mixed US inflation metrics and data-dependent Powell
content:
USD

The Buck remains somewhat betwixt and between, as the DXY trades within a 98.449-289 range and Usd/pairings broadly observe risk-off/safe-haven boundaries, with one or two major exceptions. Hardly any independent direction derived via US CPI data as the headline y/y rate printed a tad firmer than forecast in contrast to the core measure, while Fed chair Powell’s text for the JEC largely reiterated October policy guidance and the shift to pause mode with optionality to react if the favourable economic assessment changes (deteriorates) materially.

NZD

The Kiwi has been flouting the overall risk averse trend ever since the RBNZ decided to stand pat overnight against expectations for a ¼ point ease, and Governor Orr followed up with the explanation that there is no urgent need to provide more stimulus as unfolding data since August’s more aggressive than anticipated 50 bp OCR cut has essentially been offsetting (ie weaker than forecast releases countered by upside surprises). Nzd/Usd is nudging 0.6400 again awaiting more from Orr later.

CHF/JPY

Chief beneficiaries of the deterioration in sentiment following US President Trump’s NY Economic Club testimony that raised more negatives than positives regarding Phase 1 of the trade deal with China and pushback of auto tariffs awaiting the official announcement due some time later today. The Franc continues to test resistance around 0.9900 and 1.0900 vs the Greenback and Euro respectively, not to mention the resolve of the SNB that underlined the importance of NIRP and currency intervention to curb Chf strength/demand in fragile market conditions. Meanwhile, the Yen rebounded further from recent lows circa 109.50 against the Dollar, through 109.00, a 108.88 Fib and is now eyeing 108.65 (November 7 low for Usd/Jpy) in the run up to Japanese Q3 GDP data.

EUR/CAD/GBP/AUD

All on a softer footing vs the Buck, with the single currency unable to break above 1.1000, but also holding just above Fib support just under the round number in the form of a 1.0994 Fib, while the Loonie also derived some technical momentum or encouragement from the fact that the 200 DMA at 1.3277 was respected and pared losses from around 1.3268 through 1.3250. Elsewhere, Sterling has straddled 1.2850 with little reaction to UK CPI, but some pressure exerted by Brexit Party Leader Farage ramming home the message that no more candidates will be withdrawn and all Remainers will be contested at the forthcoming GE. Back down under, the Aussie has been lagging well behind its Antipodean and US peers sub-0.6850 and just shy of 1.0670 at one stage respectively awaiting further US-China trade developments and a speech from RBA Deputy Governor Bullock.

SEK/NOK/EM

A partial reprieve for the Swedish and Norwegian Kronas after early EU declines in wake of benign Swedish inflation readings as Riksbank’s Floden stuck to December tightening guidance regardless and the technical backdrop turned less bearish. Meanwhile, mixed fortunes in the EM arena where the Lira regained some poise pending news from the Turkish President Erdogan and his US adversary Trump meeting, but the Rand hampered by Eskom strife and bleak SA retail sales and the Mexican Peso defensive ahead of Thursday’s Banxico rate decision that could culminate in a bigger than forecast ½ point reduction. Conversely, the Rouble gleaned some traction from firmer than consensus Russian Q3 growth, and a mild bounce in Brent.

subject: ANALYSIS: October US CPI shows no signs of September tariffs; barring a surprise, may support Fed stance of leaving rates on hold for an extended period
content:
• There was a small upside surprise, with headline CPI rising 0.4% M/M against an expected rise of 0.3%; the Y/Y rate ticked up by one-tenth to 1.8%. 
  • The Core M/M printed 0.2%, in line with the expected, while the core Y/Y rate rose by one-tenth to 2.4% (which some analysts said was consistent with the Fed's preferred PCE gauge running at a clip slightly below 2.0%). 
  • Analysts said that the larger rise in headline prices was on the back of higher gasoline prices, with little signs of September tariff hikes lifting consumer prices, just yet (ahead of the release of the October data, analysts had suggested the impact may be more visible in the November data). 
  • "We had expected to see some inflationary impact from the latest tranche of tariffs on Chinese imports imposed in early September, but prices of clothing and household furnishings declined in October," Capital Economics said, "meanwhile, there are some signs that underlying price pressures are beginning to moderate again, with shelter prices rising by a muted 0.1% m/m." 
  • Overall, however, Capital Economics argues that the October CPI data suggests core inflation is levelling off close to the Fed's 2% target, and that barring any sharp slowdown in economic activity, that supports the Fed’s stance of leaving interest rates on hold for an extended period.

subject: PRIMER: US CPI to be released 1330 GMT/0830 ET; Street expects +0.3% M/M, 1.7% Y/Y
content:
• The Street expects US CPI to rise 0.3% M/M in October, though the Y/Y rate is seen unchanged at 1.7%; the core measure is seen rising 0.2% M/M, though again, the Y/Y rate is seen unchanged at 2.4%. Real earnings are expected to bounceback, riding 0.1% M/M (prev. -0.1%). 
  • Crucially, the data may begin reflecting the impact of the September tariff increases, UBS said, though this is likely to be more evident in the November data. Looking ahead, UBS says expects 12-month headline CPI to rise to 2.9% by late Spring due to the pass-through of tariffs not being rolled back, while core PCE is projected to hold steady around 1.7% Y/Y in October, before rising to 2.3% by late Spring. 
  • TD Securities says the recent rally in breakevens suggests that the market is more optimistic on breakeven inflation, which TD believes creates asymmetric risks into the CPI report. Adds that while a firm print could cement recent gains, a weaker reading could leave brekevens retracing sharply lower.

subject: PRIMER: Fed Chair Powell to testify to the Congressional Joint Economic Committee at 1100 ET/1600 GMT
content:
• NOTHING NEW EXPECTED: The Street is not expecting much by way of fresh remarks from Chair Powell in his remarks (Joint Economic Committee on Wednesday; House Budge Committee on Thursday). The advent of post-meeting press conferences has mitigated the impact of these testimonies, analysts have said. "There isn't much for Powell to say beyond what he delivered after the 30th October post-FOMC meeting news conference," Jefferies said, "the Fed is monitoring incoming information about the economy, but the mid-cycle adjustment process is complete for now."
  • DATA BETTER, CUT PRICING HAS LIGHTENED SLIGHTLY: Since the FOMC meeting at the end of October, jobs data and the non-manufacturing ISM data surprised to the upside, and pricing for Fed rate cuts has lightened slightly, with money markets pricing around one hike through the end of next year. BMO's analysts said "This is consistent with the Committee walking back cut expectations without tripping into a sharp tightening of financial conditions," adding that "Powell's job from here will be to walk the party line and not risk rocking the proverbial boat that has so far handled the latest pivot in stride."
  • EXPECTED MESSAGE: As a recap, at the press conference, Chair Powell suggested monetary policy was now in a good place, and the current stance of monetary policy was likely to remain appropriate, and that the risks to the outlook have moved in a positive direction (he cited US/China, as well as Brexit; noting that there is plenty of risk left, but they had subsided, and this might offer support to business investment ahead, which he did not see weakening further). Policy, however, was not on a pre-set course, Powell said, and the Fed would be prepared to adjust if there was a material change to the its outlook. the Fed Chair also said the Fed was not currently mulling rate hikes, adding that inflation would need to significantly rise before rate hikes were on the table. Powell again said that the rate cut was insurance against ongoing risks, and the accommodation provided so far will significant support the economy - the full impact would be realised over time, given the lag in monetary policy. Powell felt that the resilient consumer sector was driving growth. Overall, Powell seemed generally encouraged by the economy, repeating most of the Fed's outlook within the statement, but added that the Fed is mindful that continued below target inflation might lead to a slide in inflation expectations (he sees no risks of a significant move higher), and that weakness in global growth and trade still poses ongoing risks. All in all, and taken in combination with the statement, it indicates that the Fed's mid-cycle adjustment is over, and the Fed is now in a data-dependent approach to policy.
  • Link to Stream

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are subdued as the post-Trump underwhelming tone remains, ahead of potential Auto tariffs and Fed’s Powell
  • Tariffs are reportedly emerging as the main stumbling block for US and China to reach a limited trade deal, according to WSJ citing sources
  • NZD outperforms after the RBNZ remained on hold overnight, DXY retains some mild firmness
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI, EIA STEO, APIs, Japanese GDP, Fed’s Powell, Barkin, Kashkari, RBNZ's Orr, RBA’s Bullock; President’s Trump & Erdogan meeting (approx. 12:00ET)
  • Earnings: Cisco

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were lower across the board and US equity futures pulled back from record levels amid continued uncertainty and disappointment following US President Trump’s speech at the Economic Club of New York which failed to provide any fresh insight on US-China trade, with news the USTR office will submit a report on possible auto tariffs to the White House also clouding over the risk climate. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) declined as weakness in the energy, mining and financials sectors weighed on Australia, while Tokyo was also subdued by underperformance in commodity stocks and detrimental currency inflows. Hang Seng (-1.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) conformed to the downbeat tone after US President Trump largely stuck to the script regarding US-China trade but also renewed his criticism on China and threatened higher tariffs if they fail to reach an agreement, with the losses in Hong Kong exacerbated again due to the current no end in sight for the disruption which has already plunged the city into a recession. Finally, 10yr JGBs were in recovery mode after the prior day’s slump with the rebound aided by support around 152.50 and the broad risk averse tone in the region.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0026 vs. Exp. 7.0010 (Prev. 6.9933)

Tariffs are reportedly emerging as the main stumbling block for US and China to reach a limited trade deal, according to sources. Reports suggest that the disagreement stems on whether or not the US removes all existing tariffs in “phase one” or cancels the impending December 15th tariffs. (WSJ)

China's Cabinet says will lower capital ratio requirement for some infrastructural investments projects, according to state media. (Newswires)

US

Fed's Kashkari (2020 Voter, Dove) said he is feeling a little bit better about the US economy than a few months ago and there is a lot of consensus at the Fed that monetary policy is modestly accommodative, while he added that modestly accommodative policy is appropriate. (Newswires)

The National Association of Manufacturers was hacked over the summer and hired a cybersecurity firm, who concluded the attack came from China, according to two sources said; noting, that the incident occurred before a round of formal negotiations between US and Chinese government officials over the contents of potential deal (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK CPI YY (Oct) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.7%): BoE October forecast 1.5%

- UK Core CPI YY (Oct) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)

- UK CPI MM (Oct) -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.1%)

- UK Core CPI MM (Oct) 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%)

German CPI Final YY* (Oct) 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%); MM* (Oct) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.1%)

- HICP Final YY* (Oct) 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 0.9%); MM* (Oct) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.1%)

Swedish CPIF YY (Oct) 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.3%); Riksbank October forecast 1.58%

SNB's President Jordan says monetary policy with negative interest rates and a readiness to intervene is still necessary, CHF remains highly valued. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Senior US administration official said President Trump's priorities in northeast Syria are to prevent IS resurgence and prevent atrocities in the region, while the official added the US has no intention to end alliance with Kurdish-led SDF militia and needs to resolve the issue with Turkey regarding the latter's purchase of the Russian S-400 system. (Newswires)

Note: US President Trump and Turkish President Erdogan are due to meet today at circa 12:00 ET 

Hong Kong government suspends all schools on Thursday; separately, Chinese Universities in Hong Kong will cancel all of their on-campus classes for November in Hong Kong., SCMP understands. (Newswires/SCMP)

EQUITIES

Risk off trade sees major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 -0.8%) lower this morning, following a cautious APAC session in light of US President Trump’s disappointing speech at the Economic Club of New York and separate reports that the USTR office is to submit new potential auto tariffs which Trump could implement on the EU. Potentially contributing to the jitters; today is the approximate deadline for US President Trump to make a decision on EU auto-tariffs. European autonames, including Peugeot (-2.7%) and BMW (-2.0%), are amongst the underperformers. Sector performance is reflective of the markets lack of risk appetite; the more defensive Consumer Staples (+0.7%), Utilities (-0.5%) and Health Care (+0.2%) sectors are the outperformers, the latter buoyed by gains in GlaxoSmithKline (+0.5%), whose Phase III study of Nucala met its primary endpoint. Strong earnings from SSE (+2.0%), meanwhile, is helping to prop up the Utilities sector. The Financial sector (-2.0%) is the marked underperformer; yields have been coming off but the downside likely has as much to do with soft ABN AMRO (-5.5%) earnings. In terms of other notable movers; strong earnings from Salvatore Ferragamo (+3.3%), Bechtle (+1.6%) and Deutsche Wohnen (+1.7%) saw their respective share prices underpinned. Conversely, soft earnings from Lanxess (-3.3%) saw the Co.’s shares pressured. Elsewhere, ArcelorMittal (-3.5%) shares were on the back foot on the news that Italy’s Foreign Minister said he did not seek Chinese investors for the Ilva plant and it would be too soon to discuss alternative options. Finally, Tullow Oil (-26.0%) sunk on after the Co.’s FY19 group oil production forecast came in slightly below guidance, largely due to performance in Ghana.

Alibaba (BABA) is reportedly testing investor appetite for an up to USD 15bln offering that prices this month; may offer stock at 5% discount in Hong Kong, according to Nikkei citing sources. (Nikkei)

FX

NZD/AUD/CAD - In stark contrast to its non-US Dollar counterparts and other high beta/risk sensitive currencies, the Kiwi is sharply outperforming, albeit off 0.6400+ overnight highs vs the Greenback and 1.0670 against the Aussie, on the back of an unexpected unchanged OCR from the RBNZ. To recap, the Bank confounded forecasts for a 25 bp cut that were underpinned and actually rising in wake of a dip in NZ inflation projections just ahead of the latest policy meeting, but the RBNZ opted to hold fire given no immediate need to ease further at the current juncture and with Governor Orr noting that data since the August assessment has been broadly balanced (netting beats and misses vs consensus). Conversely, Aud/Usd is languishing towards the base of a 0.6825-60 range and Usd/Cad has rebounded back above 1.3250 amidst a broad downturn in risk appetite and less optimism on the global trade front after US President Trump failed deliver good news about Phase 1 or auto tariffs late yesterday.

CHF - The next best G10 performer and only partially heeding more verbal SNB intervention following a meeting with the Swiss Government to discuss a variety of issues, but pertinently fragile FX markets and a Franc that is still deemed to be highly valued. Usd/Chf skirting 0.9900 and Eur/Chf 1.0900.

GBP/JPY/EUR - All relatively flat or rangebound against the Buck as Cable pivots 1.2850 and largely shrugs off UK inflation data including headline CPI that slowed to 1.5% vs 1.6% expected, but bang in line with the BoE estimate, while the Yen straddles 109.00 and Euro holds above 1.1000, albeit after a miniscule downside breach and as the DXY drifts back from a fresh recent peak of 98.449 to the middle of its band (down to 98.289 at the other extreme).

NOK/SEK - The Scandi Crowns are slipping in wake of more Swedish data raising questions over the Riksbank’s commitment to hiking the repo in December, with Eur/Sek up over 10.4400 at one stage and Eur/Nok soaking up offers at 10.1600 before fading and also fuelled by a retracement in crude prices

EM - Amidst widespread losses vs the Dollar, Usd/Zar has revisited 15.0000+ territory against the backdrop of Eskom’s ongoing power travails and with SA retail sales missing the mark by some distance. However, Usd/Try is hovering below highs ahead of Turkish President Erdogan’s meeting with his US peer and Usd/Rub is meandering mid-range into Russian Q3 GDP and after the Finance Minister pulled a 2025 OFZ offering.

RBNZ kept the Official Cash Rate unchanged at 1.00% vs. consensus for a 25bps cut, while it said it is prepared to act and will add further monetary stimulus if needed but noted economic developments do not warrant a change to monetary policy at this time and that low rates, as well as government spending will support domestic demand. RBNZ Governor Orr also commented there was no urgency to further ease at this point and suggested ups and downs in data since the August statement broadly offsets each other, while RBNZ's Hawkesby commented that data will determine what the RBNZ does. (Newswires)

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1015 (550M), 1.1035-50 (1.5BLN)

- EUR/GBP: 0.8500 (1.1BLN), 0.8550 (200M), 0.8650 (350M), 0.8700 (755M)

- USD/CAD: 1.3150 (266M), 1.3215 (1BLN), 1.3260 (425M)

FIXED INCOME

Bonds have eased back off best levels, but remain firmly bid and in demand almost across the board amidst a deeper retracement in risk assets after US President Trump underwhelmed in terms of bullish trade expectations. Bunds, Gilts and 10 year US T-notes have been as high as 170.25, 131.41 and 128-27+, with the former somewhat stymied by a rather lacklustre German auction and with the focus shifting to a packed pm agenda including CPI, Fed chair Powell and colleagues.

COMMODITIES

The crude complex is lower, in fitting with the market’s risk-off feel. Front month WTI and Brent futures have been moving lower in line with equities, with WTI earlier testing Monday’s USD 56.25/bbl low and Brent easily clearing this level and making progress towards last week’s USD 60.70/bbl low (although, at USD 61.30/bbl, Brent is still some way off). In terms of crude specific developments; ahead of the December 5-6th OPEC and OPEC+ meetings, OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said it is too early to say if further output cuts are needed. As a reminder; sources have noted that Saudi Arabia and Russia do not want to bear the brunt of deeper reductions, with the former wanting members to comply with the current pact, which could see around 500k BPD out of the market. In separate news, the IEA forecast that global oil demand growth is expected to slow from 2025 as fuel efficiency improves and the use of electrified vehicles increases but is unlikely to peak in the next two decades. Elsewhere, Nigeria's NNPC said current crude output stands at 1.6-1.7mln bpd (vs. 1.93mln in October), and assured the nation will continue to comply with OPEC cuts. Looking ahead, EIA’s Short-Term Energy Outlook is set for release in the afternoon, followed by API Inventory data after the US equity market close, both having been delayed one day due to a Monday holiday in the US. Over in metals, gold prices are modestly firmer and Copper softer, as the broader lack of risk appetite gives havens a boost at the expense of more risk sensitive assets. Following a steep decline so far in the month of November, the precious metal has managed to stabilise, and reclaim the USD 1460/oz mark from USD 1450/oz lows. Meanwhile, downside for copper is being cushioned on the news that further strikes are disrupting operations at Chilean Codelco's northern copper mines.

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo says it is too early to say if further output cuts are needed. (Newswires)

IEA said the world energy outlook central scenario is for global oil demand growth to rise 1mln bpd annually to 2025 then increase 100k bpd annually during 2030s, while it sees oil prices at nearly USD 90/bbl in 2030 and USD 103/bbl in 2040. (Newswires)

Port Hedland October iron ore exports to China 35.8mln tons vs. Prev. 36.05mln M/M and 32.8mln tons Y/Y. (Newswires)

content: Gilts have lost a bit of momentum after a modestly firm start to Wednesday’s Liffe session and early foray above 131.00 in line with Bunds that continue to fade on approaches to their nearest big figure and Short Sterling contracts in a tight band around parity (-1/+2 ticks). However, the 10 year UK benchmark retains a solid underlying bid on renewed risk aversion or at least less bullish sentiment surrounding global trade after remarks from US President Trump on the current state of play failed to match the upbeat hype stirred by reports that the first part of a wider deal is in the offing. Turning to today’s domestic agenda, CPI data will take centre stage, albeit with little potential to move markets given consensus for steady headline and core readings. Back to Liffe, Gilts are hovering around 131.00 between 130.86-131.07 parameters vs yesterday’s 130.78 close.

Bunds: reloading after opening mark-up and fade
content: Nothing to glean from final and unrevised German inflation data, but the core Eurozone bond has bounced further from Tuesday’s intraday low to retest resistance ahead of 170.00 on the back of another downturn in risk appetite following US President Trump’s address at the NY Economic Club that confounded expectations in terms of adding something constructive on the progression towards a Phase 1 trade accord with China. In fact his comments could be construed quite incendiary as he warned that no deal would illicit even higher tariffs, and he also refrained from talking about auto levies in the context of a potential rollback. Looking at Eurex price action thus far, Bunds have been in a 169.94-67 range, awaiting Eurozone IP, 10 year German issuance, US CPI and Fed speak including chair Powell at the JEC.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were lower across the board and US equity futures pulled back from record levels
  • US President Trump’s speech failed to provide any fresh insight on US-China trade but continued to warn the US will substantially raise tariffs on Chinese imports if there is no deal made
  • US Trade Representative's Office will submit a report on possible tariffs on autos and auto parts to the White House by today
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German, Swedish, UK CPI, EU Industrial Output, US CPI, EIA STEO, APIs, Japanese GDP, Fed’s Powell, Barkin, Kashkari, RBNZ's Orr, RBA’s Bullock, Riksbank’s Floden, supply from Germany & Italy
  • Earnings: Bechtle, Deutsche Wohnen, Altice, ABN Amro, Lanxess, SSE, Cisco, Applied Materials

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were lower across the board and US equity futures pulled back from record levels amid continued uncertainty and disappointment following US President Trump’s speech at the Economic Club of New York which failed to provide any fresh insight on US-China trade, with news the USTR office will submit a report on possible auto tariffs to the White House also clouding over the risk climate. ASX 200 (-0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) declined as weakness in the energy, mining and financials sectors weighed on Australia, while Tokyo was also subdued by underperformance in commodity stocks and detrimental currency inflows. Hang Seng (-2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) conformed to the downbeat tone after US President Trump largely stuck to the script regarding US-China trade but also renewed his criticism on China and threatened higher tariffs if they fail to reach an agreement, with the losses in Hong Kong exacerbated again due to the current no end in sight for the disruption which has already plunged the city into a recession. Finally, 10yr JGBs were in recovery mode after the prior day’s slump with the rebound aided by support around 152.50 and the broad risk averse tone in the region.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0026 vs. Exp. 7.0010 (Prev. 6.9933)

US President Trump said we are close to signing Phase One with China which could happen soon but will only accept it if it is good for the US and its workers. Trump reiterated that China has cheated the US since joining the WTO and has been manipulating its currency, while he added China is making large agricultural purchases and warned the US will substantially raise tariffs on Chinese imports if there is no deal made. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said he would not put a timeline on a China trade deal and noted that "close" means "close", while he reiterated lots of progress on IP theft, financial services, currency stability, commodities and agriculture. Kudlow added that neither side is going to agree to any tariff adjustments until a deal is reached and that it is possible tariff adjustments could be part of the deal. (CNBC)

China Global Times Editor stated there are quite a lot of criticisms and complaints from President Trump about China in his latest speech but there was hardly anything new and similar statements of senior US officials have bored people, while the editor added it seems the US administration believes a lie repeated a thousand times becomes truth. (Twitter) Tariffs are reportedly emerging as the main stumbling block for US and China to reach a limited trade deal, according to sources. Reports suggest that the disagreement stems on whether or not the US removes all existing tariffs in “phase one” or cancels the impending December 15th tariffs. (WSJ)

UK/EU

Brexit Party Leader Farage said 300 seat nominations have been signed off as part of its fight against the Labour Party. (Newswires)

YouGov Poll: Conservatives 42%, Labour 28%, Lib Dems 15%, Brexit Party 4%, Green 4%. This poll was carried out on November 11-12th (Newswires)

US President Trump criticized the EU for having "terrible trade barriers" which he suggested in some cases, can be worse than China. In other news, US President Trump and French President Macron had a call on Monday in which Trump stressed the need for a level playing field for US companies and they also reaffirmed their commitment to work together on Syria. (Newswires)

FX

DXY traded sideways within a tight range after the lack of fresh trade insight from US President Trump with the greenback’s major counterparts mixed with EUR/USD subdued as it just about held onto the 1.1000 handle following mixed German ZEW data and the lingering threat of auto tariffs stateside, while GBP/USD consolidated around 1.2850 amid very light pertinent newsflow and as the latest Survation and YouGov polls suggested the Conservatives remained ahead of the opposition Labour Party, albeit by a varying degree of 6-14 points. Elsewhere, USD/JPY briefly slipped below the 109.00 handle due to the subdued risk appetite and antipodeans outperformed with NZD/USD boosted after the RBNZ’s surprise decision to keep the OCR unchanged in which it stated it will act if needed but added that economic developments do not warrant a change to monetary policy at this time.

RBNZ kept the Official Cash Rate unchanged at 1.00% vs. consensus for a 25bps cut, while it said it is prepared to act and will add further monetary stimulus if needed but noted economic developments do not warrant a change to monetary policy at this time and that low rates, as well as government spending will support domestic demand. RBNZ Governor Orr also commented there was no urgency to further ease at this point and suggested ups and downs in data since the August statement broadly offsets each other, while RBNZ's Hawkesby commented that data will determine what the RBNZ does. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mostly lower with price action subdued by the broad risk averse tone which weighed on WTI crude futures towards USD 56.50/bbl where prices eventually found support. There were also recent comments from a Gulf OPEC delegate which suggested the unlikelihood for deeper production cuts as the resulting increase in prices from such action would spur a boost in US output and effectively nullify their efforts, while focus now shifts to the upcoming inventory reports which were delayed due to this week’s Veterans Day. Elsewhere, gold prices were marginally supported by safe-haven demand but with gains limited by a steady greenback, and copper languished at this month’s lows amid the widespread downbeat sentiment.

IEA said the world energy outlook central scenario is for global oil demand growth to rise 1mln bpd annually to 2025 then increase 100k bpd annually during 2030s, while it sees oil prices at nearly USD 90/bbl in 2030 and USD 103/bbl in 2040. (Newswires)

Port Hedland October iron ore exports to China 35.8mln tons vs. Prev. 36.05mln M/M and 32.8mln tons Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Senior US administration official said President Trump's priorities in northeast Syria are to prevent IS resurgence and prevent atrocities in the region, while the official added the US has no intention to end alliance with Kurdish-led SDF militia and needs to resolve the issue with Turkey regarding the latter's purchase of the Russian S-400 system. (Newswires) 

US

 

The TPLEX traded choppy and rangebound on Tuesday where Trump’s anticipated speech failed to provide key details on the trade fronts with both China and the EU. Meanwhile, AbbVie (ABBV) gained the title of the year’s largest issuer after its USD 30bln M&A bond for its acquisition of Allergan (AGN). Yields were little changed at settlement with the 2s10s still gravitating around 26bps. US T-note (Z9) futures settled 4+ ticks higher at 128-17.

US President Trump repeated familiar criticisms of the Fed and talked up his achievements on the economy since coming into office. Trump commented the US can bring taxes lower and talked up further regulation cuts, while he also called for passage on USMCA in which he noted that most democrats would vote for it if there were a vote today. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative's Office will submit a report on possible tariffs on autos and auto parts to the White House by today which could allow Trump to target specific countries and EU for auto-tariffs. Furthermore, the report is said to be separate from the Commerce Department Section 232 report on tariffs on autos and auto parts and the President has until today to decide whether to act or to delay action on that report, according to Fox's Lawrence. (Fox/Twitter)

NEC Director Kudlow said US President Trump has asked him to work on tax reform 2.0 but did not provide any details as it is too early, while Kudlow said he does not think the US needs negative rates right now as the economy is in a strong place and noted the yield curve is normalising which is a good thing. (CNBC)

White House Economic advisers are reportedly considering whether to campaign on a 15% tax rate proposal for middle class income earners. (Washington Post)

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) said policy is in a mildly accommodative place after the rate cuts this year and current inflation is not the worst outcome given that expectations seem well anchored. Barkin added he does not expect rate cuts to make a big difference in investment and that weak investment is more a product of overall climate for business, uncertainty over trade, regulation and geopolitics. (Newswires)

Fed's Harker (Non-Voter, Hawk) said he was against the October rate cut and that by lowering rates further at this point the response won't be what is expected because the cost of capital is not holding businesses back, while Harker added he is currently not for raising nor lowering rates and that monetary policy is about neutral or slightly accommodative. Harker also suggested that in the case of a recession the best response is not negative rates but larger fiscal stimulus and the first line of defense would be bringing rates to zero as well as asset purchases. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashskari (Non-Voter, Dove) said he is feeling a little bit better about the US economy than a few months ago and there is a lot of consensus at the Fed that monetary policy is modestly accommodative, while he added that modestly accommodative policy is appropriate. (Newswires)

ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) are lower as weakness in the energy, mining and financials sectors weigh on Australia, while Tokyo is also subdued by declines in commodity stocks and detrimental currency inflows. Hang Seng (-2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) conform to the downbeat tone after US President Trump largely stuck to the script regarding US-China trade but also renewed his criticism on China and threatened higher tariffs if they fail to reach an agreement, with the losses in Hong Kong exacerbated again amid no end in sight for the ongoing disruption which has already plunged the city into a recession.

In FX markets, the DXY continues to trade sideways within a tight range following the lack of fresh trade insights from US President Trump who also renewed his criticism on the Fed and called for negative rates. The greenback’s major counterparts are mixed with EUR/USD subdued as it just about holds onto the 1.1000 handle following mixed German ZEW data and the lingering threat of auto tariffs stateside, while GBP/USD consolidates around 1.2850 due to light pertinent newsflow and with the latest polls by Survation and YouGov continuing to suggest the Conservatives remain ahead of the opposition Labour Party, albeit by a varying degree of 6-13 points. Elsewhere, USD/JPY briefly slipped below the 109.00 handle due to the subdued risk appetite and antipodeans outperform with NZD/USD boosted after the RBNZ’s surprise decision to keep the OCR unchanged in which it stated it will act if needed but added that economic developments do not warrant a change to monetary policy at this time.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are in recovery mode after the prior day’s slump with the rebound aided by support around 152.50 and the broad risk averse tone in the region.

RBNZ says prepared to act and will add further monetary stimulus if needed
content:
Says:

  • Employment is around sustainable level and inflation within target.
  • Low rates and government spending is to support domestic demand.
  • Economic developments do not warrant a change to monetary policy at this time.
  • Committee noted risks to the economy are tilted to the downside.
  • Committee agreed reduction in OCR over the year was transmitting through the economy and would take time to have full effect.

Forecasts

  • Sees OCR at 0.9% in March 2020 vs. Prev. 1.08%.
  • Sees OCR at 0.9% in December 2020 vs. Prev. 0.91%.
  • Sees OCR at 0.9% in March 2021 vs. Prev. 0.91%.
  • Sees annual CPI at 1.9% by December 2020 vs. Prev. 1.8%.
  • Sees December 2020 TWI NZD at 71.5% vs. Prev. forecast at 72.8%.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: US President Trump's speech failed to provide fresh insight on US-China trade
content:
Hua Hong Semiconductor (1347 HK) - Co. Q3 net USD 45.2mln vs. Prev. USD 48.3mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

IMAX China Holding (1970 HK) - Co. CEO Chen is to step down and Edwin Tan has been named as the successor. (Newswires)

MTR (66 HK) - Co. said its East Rail lines service has been suspended amid vandalism at stations. (Newswires)

Alibaba (BABA) - Co. received exchange approval for Hong Kong listing. (SCMP)

Financials - CBIRC is to set up long-term mechanism to encourage bank lending to small businesses and will conduct cross-region liquidity support to ensure liquidity of rural commercial banks. (Newswires)

Trade

US President Trump said we are close to signing Phase One with China which could happen soon but will only accept it if it is good for the US and its workers. Trump reiterated that China has cheated the US since joining the WTO and has been manipulating its currency, while he added China is making large agricultural purchases and warned the US will substantially raise tariffs on Chinese imports if there is no deal made. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said he would not put a timeline on a China trade deal and noted that "close" means "close", while he reiterated lots of progress on IP theft, financial services, currency stability, commodities and agriculture. Kudlow added that neither side is going to agree to any tariff adjustments until a deal is reached and that it is possible tariff adjustments could be part of the deal. (CNBC)

Tariffs are reportedly emerging as the main stumbling block in efforts for US and China to reach a limited trade deal, according to sources. (WSJ)

China Global Times Editor stated there are quite a lot of criticisms and complaints from President Trump about China in his latest speech but there was hardly anything new and similar statements of senior US officials have bored people, while the editor added it seems US administration believes a lie repeated a thousand times becomes truth. (Twitter)

subject: Tariffs are reportedly emerging as the main stumbling block in efforts for US and China to reach a limited trade deal, according to WSJ citing sources
